Introduction

Factually, using CLPP library add up to only two tasks:
  • registration set of parameters, with definition all required checkings and characteristics,
  • parsing inputed parameter(s), with defined check(s) and calls of corresponding functions.

Value or not value?

Command line parameter can be with or without value.

Example of parameter without value: 

 # ./program --help
Parameter '--help' is useful of its own accord, it not need any value.

Example of parameter with value: 

 # ./program --log-dir=/some/path
Parameter '--log-dir', in contrast, useless without value.


Necessity

Command line parameter can be necessary or optionally.

In examples above parameter '--help' is optionally, because it may missing (only in cases where user want to see help info, he input '--help').

But parameter '--log-dir' may be necessary, in this case user must input it.


Default value

Command line parameter can have default value, in this case not required input it. This option can be useful for parameters with predefined default values.

In example above parameter '--log-dir' may have default value of path, so user can skip it.


Error reports

All reports about errors begins with [CLPP] prefix, for example:

 [CLPP] You inputs 3 parameters, but only 2 registered!

Common usage

This section describes common usage of CLPP.


Preparing

Copy 'clpp' folder in some place where your compiler is looking for header files and add:

 #include <clpp/parser.hpp>

in your program.

For simplicity, you can also add:

 using namespace clpp;

Note: In old versions of library used namespace clp_parser, but backward compatibility is maintained.


Defining command line parameter

Registration of new parameter included three tasks:
  • define parameter's name (short and full names, or single name),
  • define function that will be called if corresponding parameter will be inputed,
  • define checks and default value for parameter (optionally).
Use clpp::command_line_parameters_parser::add_parameter() function for it.

 void help() { /* some info */ }
 void config() { /* some config info */ }
 
 int main( int argc, char* argv[] ) {
     clpp::command_line_parameters_parser parser;
     // Register parameter with two names (in Unix-style) and 'help()' function.
     parser.add_parameter( "-h", "--help", help );
     // Register parameter with single name and 'config()' function.
     parser.add_parameter( "--config", config );
     // ...
 }


Register of functions-members

You can register not only global functions, but also functions-members.

 struct some_parameters_storage {
     void some_path( const std::string& path ) { /* Some work with path... */ }
     void some_num( double number ) { /* Some work with number... */ }
 }

 int main( int argc, char* argv[] ) {
     some_parameters_storage storage;
    
     clpp::command_line_parameters_parser parser;
     parser.add_parameter( "-f", "--file", &storage, &some_parameters_storage::some_path );
     parser.add_parameter( "-n", "--number", &storage, &some_parameters_storage::some_num );
     // ...
 }


Parsing

For parsing use clpp::command_line_parameters_parser::parse() function.

 int main( int argc, char* argv[] ) {
     clpp::command_line_parameters_parser parser;
     // ...
     try {
         parser.parse( argc, argv );
     } catch ( const std::exception& exc ) {
         std::cerr << exc.what() << std::endl;
     }
     // ...
 }

This function parse all inputed command line parameters, checks correctness and calls corresponding functions.


Supported types of user's function argument

When you register parameter with value, you can use follow types of function's argument:
  • almost all standard C++-types (see below),
  • std::string.
You CANNOT use const char* and wchar_t argument. But this limitation, in my humble opinion, is not the real problem.

You can pass argument by value, like this: 

 void f( int i ) { /* some work... */ }
or by const reference: 
 void f( const std::string& path ) { /* some work... */ }

Passing by non-const reference is NOT supported (I think this is completely unnecessary).

Advanced usage

This section describes advanced usage of CLPP.


Define parameter's necessity

For define parameter's necessity use clpp::parameter::necessary() function: 
 void config( const std::string& path ) { /* some config info */ }

 int main( int argc, char* argv[] ) {
     clpp::command_line_parameters_parser parser;
     parser.add_parameter( "-c", "--config", config )
           .necessary();
     // ...
 }
After that user must inputs this parameter in command line.


Define parameter's default value

For set parameter's default value use clpp::parameter::default_value() function: 
 void config( const std::string& path ) { /* some config info */ }

 int main( int argc, char* argv[] ) {
     clpp::command_line_parameters_parser parser;
     parser.add_parameter( "-c", "--config", config )
           .default_value( "/some/default/path" );
     // ...
 }
After that user can skip this parameter in command line.


Parameter's value type check

Since 1.0rc version value's type checks automatically. If you register callback function 
 void some_num( double num ) { /* some work... */ }

 int main( int argc, char* argv[] ) {
     clpp::command_line_parameters_parser parser;
     parser.add_parameter( "-n", "--number", some_num );
     // ...
 }
so number's value must be 'double' type.

Note: if you want use function with 'float' argument, like this:

 void some_num( float num ) { /* some work... */ }
AND use 'default_value()' function, you must indicate exactly 'float' type, like this:

     // ...
     parser.add_parameter( "-n", "--number", some_num )
           .default_value( 12.56f )
           ;
     // ...
or like this:

     // ...
     parser.add_parameter( "-n", "--number", some_num )
           .default_value( float( 12.56 ) )
           ;
     // ...


Parameter's value semantic check

Use clpp::parameter::check_semantic() function.

 void log_dir( const std::string& path_to_log ) { /* some work... */ }

 int main( int argc, char* argv[] ) {
     clpp::command_line_parameters_parser parser;
     parser.add_parameter( "-l", "--log-dir", log_dir )
           .check_semantic( clpp::path );
     // ...
 }

In this case, value of '--log-dir' must be valid path in current filesystem.

Supported value's semantic:

  • path (check of path correctness, in current filesystem),
  • ipv4 (check of IP-address validity, exactly IPv4),
  • ipv6 (check of IP-address validity, exactly IPv6),
  • ip (check of IP-address validity, IPv4 or IPv6).
  • email (check of E-mail validity).

Combine of settings

Of course, you can combine settings for one parameter, like this:

 void log_dir( const std::string& path_to_log ) { /* some work... */ } 

 int main( int argc, char* argv[] ) {
     clpp::command_line_parameters_parser parser;
     parser.add_parameter( "-l", "--log-dir", log_dir )
           .default_value( "/some/default/path" )
           .check_semantic( clpp::path )
           ;
     // ...
 }

Note: You cannot combine contradictory settings. For example, if you write like this:

 void log_dir( const std::string& path_to_log ) { /* some work... */ }
 
 int main( int argc, char* argv[] ) {
     clpp::command_line_parameters_parser parser;
     parser.add_parameter( "-l", "--log-dir", log_dir )
           .default_value( "/some/default/path" )
           .check_semantic( clpp::path )
           .necessary() // Necessary parameter with defined default value?? Hmm...
           ;
     // ...
 }

exception will throw.


Another 'name-value' separator

You can define another 'name-value' separator, instead default '='.

Use clpp::command_line_parameters_parser::set_value_separator() function.

 int main( int argc, char* argv[] ) {
     clpp::command_line_parameters_parser parser;
     parser.set_value_separator( ':' );
     // ...
 }

In this case, parameters with value must be input in command line like this:

 # ./program --log-dir:/some/path

Note: You CANNOT use characters with ASCII-code less than 0x21. They are unsuitable candidates for the separator role. :-)


Unnamed parameters

Sometimes you may want to use some parameters without explicitly inputed names.

For example, if you develop network program with console-defined host and port, you can use it like this:

 # ./program --host=127.0.0.1 --port=80

but you probably want to use it easier:

 # ./program 127.0.0.1 80

Use clpp::parameter::order() function.

This function sets order number for parameter, so in our example 'host' has order number 1, and 'port' has order number 2. Note that order number begins with 1, because it is not index, but exactly number.

Of course, order number cannot be negative.

So you must register these parameters like this:

 struct my_server {
     void host( const std::string& address ) { /* some work... */ }
     void port( unsigned int some_port ) { /* some work... */ }
 };

 int main( int argc, char* argv[] ) {
     my_server server;
     
     clpp::command_line_parameters_parser parser;
     parser.add_parameter( "-h", "--host", &server, &my_server::host )
           .order( 1 )
           ;
     parser.add_parameter( "-p", "--port", &server, &my_server::port )
           .order( 2 )
           ;
     // ...
 }

Now you can use it like this:

 # ./program 127.0.0.1 80

but not vice versa:

 # ./program 80 127.0.0.1

because in this case my_server::port() function get string-argument, and exception will throw.

Remember that order numbers must be unique:

     // ...
     parser.add_parameter( "-h", "--host", &server, &my_server::host )
           .order( 1 )
           ;
     parser.add_parameter( "-p", "--port", &server, &my_server::port )
           .order( 1 ) // You inputed already used order?? Hmm...
           ;
     // ...

Of course, you can use "ordered" parameters with names, in any combination:

 # ./program -h=127.0.0.1 --port=80

 # ./program 127.0.0.1 -p=80
